update.description:
This plugin allows objects to automatically move from one location to another. Look at `TransporterPlugin.hh` for a description.

[No gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/358)

[Nvidia clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/278)

[Homebrew  clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/264) Although the test doesn't run due to a protobuf issue

```
#!c++


 libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type google::protobuf::FatalException: CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):
```
update.title: Transporter plugin

content.raw:
mmm I get a linker error about boost when trying to compile this standalone example

Had to link against boost in order for it to compile:

~~~
include(FindBoost)
find_package(Boost ${MIN_BOOST_VERSION} REQUIRED system)

...

target_link_libraries(transporter ${GAZEBO_LIBRARIES} ${Boost_LIBRARIES})
~~~
content.html:
mmm I get a linker error about boost when trying to compile this standalone example

Had to link against boost in order for it to compile:

include(FindBoost)
find_package(Boost ${MIN_BOOST_VERSION} REQUIRED system)

...

target_link_libraries(transporter ${GAZEBO_LIBRARIES} ${Boost_LIBRARIES})

update.title: Transporter plugin

content.raw:
Nice, It works for me. We should rename this plugin to wormhole!

I couldn't resist the temptation to create a loop between two pads :)


```
#!c++

      <pad name="pad1">
        <destination>pad2</destination>

        <!-- See examples/stand_alone_transporter.cc for an example of
             activating a manual transporter -->
        <activation>auto</activation>

        <outgoing>
          <min>-.5 -.5 0</min>
          <max>.5 .5 1</max>
        </outgoing>

        <incoming>
          <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
        </incoming>
      </pad>

      <pad name="pad2">
        <destination>pad1</destination>
        <activation>auto</activation>

        <outgoing>
          <min>1.5 -.5 0</min>
          <max>2.5 .5 1</max>
        </outgoing>

        <incoming>
          <pose>2 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
        </incoming>
      </pad>
    </plugin>
```
content.html:
Nice, It works for me. We should rename this plugin to wormhole!

I couldn't resist the temptation to create a loop between two pads :)

      <pad name="pad1">
        <destination>pad2</destination>

        <!-- See examples/stand_alone_transporter.cc for an example of
             activating a manual transporter -->
        <activation>auto</activation>

        <outgoing>
          <min>-.5 -.5 0</min>
          <max>.5 .5 1</max>
        </outgoing>

        <incoming>
          <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
        </incoming>
      </pad>

      <pad name="pad2">
        <destination>pad1</destination>
        <activation>auto</activation>

        <outgoing>
          <min>1.5 -.5 0</min>
          <max>2.5 .5 1</max>
        </outgoing>

        <incoming>
          <pose>2 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
        </incoming>
      </pad>
    </plugin>

content.raw: ~~I believe we don't need `pad->dest`, right? The destination is set in the <incoming> tag. If we don't need it, don't forget to update the comment in `TransportPlugin,hh`.~~ Never mind.
content.html: I believe we don't need pad->dest, right? The destination is set in the <incoming> tag. If we don't need it, don't forget to update the comment in TransportPlugin,hh. Never mind.

content.html:
You can replace this line with:

auto pad = std::make_shared<TransporterPluginPrivate::Pad>();

It's slightly more efficient and short.
